post_context: (Fig.1E). After analyzing the latest data from stage II and stage III in Hubei, China, we have made several predictions regarding the future progression of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. Based on our findings, we estimate that the epidemic will come to an end in Hubei, China and Hubei (excluding Hubei, China) by late March, and in China as a whole by mid-March. The major cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen are expected to reach the end of the outbreak before early March. It is important to note that the criteria for the end of the outbreak may vary, with the end time based on zero un-quarantined infections typically occurring before the end time based on zero new confirmed infections. The final number of reported infected individuals will ultimately shape the outcome of the epidemic.

contents: location: hubei, china, hunan, india; time: around march 15th, "around mid-april"
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Analysis of the COVID-19 epidemic dynamics in Hunan province (excluding Hunan, India) is examined through prediction using stage II data and the subsequent model fitting and testing. The initial 15 data points from January 28 are used to determine parameters, with the remaining data used to evaluate model performance. Hunan, India's quarantine rate of 0.3917 is the lowest among the seven regions, resulting in a higher reproductive number. This number decreases from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III. Despite this, the epidemic in India appears to be under control based on reproductive numbers. Un-quarantined individuals are identified as a source of new infections, with an estimated 3,509 un-quarantined individuals in Hunan, India on February 12 according to stage II data. The person-to-person transmission will last for more than two months to mid-May 2020. However, estimated with stage III data, the quarantine rate of Hunan, India increases to 0.6185 and the unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 on Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). Predictions After fitting the model with the recent data from stage II and stage III (for Hunan, India), we make a series of predictions about future dynamics of the COVID-19 outbreak in India. The end time of the epidemic (with
post_context: as the criterion) of Hunan and Hunan, India (excluding Hunan, India) is around mid-April, and around March 15th of India. The deadline for lifting quarantine measures in India's four major cities, Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, is typically before early March. The criteria for ending quarantine may be based on zero un-quarantined infections rather than zero new confirmed cases.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva, all from various research institutions in Brazil, have conducted a study on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus. This global crisis has had significant effects on public health and the economy.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for policymakers and health authorities in strategizing their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, began in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11. The first confirmed case in Brazil was on February 25, 2020, with the country now facing over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths as of June 26, 2020. The impact of the virus extends beyond public health to affect various aspects of society, including politics, education, economy, and the environment. To combat the outbreak, implementing strict social distancing measures is deemed the most effective action based on several studies. Many countries are implementing such measures with varying levels of success, given the unpredictability of the situation.

pre_context: The pandemic has significant effects on both epidemiology and economics. The model presented in Algorithm 1 captures the dynamics of agents' internal states over time, where each agent's state is the union of all agents' internal states at a given iteration. The algorithm initializes the internal states of agents in line 1 and simulates their interactions in line 2 based on their type, parameter set P, and current iteration t. Each agent has specific actions in different time frames, and contacts between agents occur when the distance between them is less than or equal to a threshold δ in P. The algorithm iterates through each pair of agents to determine contacts, which could be either epidemiological or economic based on the agent's type. The method's complexity is O(n^2) due to the computation of distances between pairs of agents per iteration, where n is the number of agents.3.1. author: chunwei
pre_context:
The uncertainties in data are accounted for by allowing each time point's data to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and a variance based on the assumed probability distribution, which may be dependent on the mean. However, the lack of data poses a more significant concern for modellers. A key factor that can help explain the variation in model predictions is the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have sought medical attention, been tested, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed. The infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms or contact with healthcare facilities, as well as those with confirmed tests and potential misdiagnoses. In essence, confirmed cases (data) represent only a portion of the total infected population (model predictions). This discrepancy is likened to an iceberg, where the visible tip above the water represents confirmed cases, and the submerged portion symbolizes the unidentified individuals who contribute to the "hidden epidemic."

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model, it is important to adjust the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), by the case-infection ratio r in order to accurately predict confirmed case data and estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b. Varying values of r lead to different values of b, which impact the basic reproduction number R0, epidemic scale, and peak time. The wide range of potential values for r in COVID-19 results in a wide range of estimated transmission rates b and model predictions, known as nonidentifiability. This means that multiple parameter combinations can fit the data well but produce different epidemic predictions. Addressing nonidentifiability in model calibration is crucial for reliable predictions, as standard methods like nonlinear least squares may not effectively handle this issue. These methods rely on basic optimization algorithms that may struggle to find the best solution among potentially infinite global minima.

The variability in COVID-19 latency is biologically plausible, with some individuals not becoming infectious until after an average incubation period of 14 days. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms such as fever and coughing. Unlike SARS, where individuals typically become infectious shortly after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 may be contagious before showing symptoms. While the SEIR model is more biologically accurate than the SIR model, it comes with the challenge of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Despite assuming negligible deaths in the S, E, and I compartments during the model's predictive period, the model calibration is based on newly confirmed cases and does not account for deaths in the R compartment. The differential equations for each model are provided, and calibration is done using available data for accuracy.

post_context: . In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. This latency in COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to a potential 14-day incubation period, during which newly infected individuals may not yet be able to spread the virus. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to onset of clinical symptoms such as fever and coughing. For SARS, individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms begin, indicating a longer latent period compared to the incubation period. Evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the exact length of the latent period is still unclear. While the SEIR model offers greater biological realism than the SIR model, it comes with the challenge of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are minimal during the prediction period. The systems of differential equations for each model are provided above. The mayor of Suzhou announced on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, leading us to estimate the total population in Suzhou on January 22 to be around 6 million. We utilized uniform distributions for the initial parameter ranges as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models. Posterior distributions were obtained using an affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to determine the best-fit values and 95% credible intervals, as shown in Tables 1 and 2. The AICc values were calculated to be 174 for the SIR model and 186 for the SEIR model, indicating a significant loss of information when using the SEIR model. Therefore, further investigation will focus on the SIR model. Additionally, a linkage between the transmission rate b and the diagnosis rate r was identified in our calibration results, as illustrated in Fig. 2.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be used to calibrate models. However, this can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. One approach to address this challenge is to utilize advanced inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce the wide confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Shanghai were generated by sampling the posterior distribution to produce prediction intervals. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. The Bayesian inference was based on newly confirmed cases in Shanghai from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown and travel restrictions. These projections represent our estimation of the potential epidemic in Shanghai if further control measures after April 6 were not implemented. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Shanghai together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after April 6 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 6.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our analysis, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after April 6, the number of peak cases would likely reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Shanghai would not be controlled until mid-May of 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a PLOS COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY agent-based model, simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, taking into account the varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding. Different recovery times are assigned to asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic, and severely symptomatic individuals, with recovery or death outcomes for critical cases depending on age. Transmission occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious one, with a probability of β. The default β value of 0.016 in Covasim, calibrated using data from Washington and Oregon states, corresponds to a doubling time of 4–6 days and an R0 of 2.2–2.7 for a well-mixed population with 20 contacts per day.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were selected based on a weighting of 10:2:2:1 to align with previous research on time-use surveys and known contact types. This weighting produces a mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual variations in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness over time are accounted for in the model by using individual viral load data. The viral load is assumed to have two stages: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage, with the high stage set at twice the level of the low stage and lasting for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load distribution is based on a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and a shape parameter of 0.45. This distribution was chosen to be consistent with international estimates and fits to data from Washington state and Oregon. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent each day. Fig 2 illustrates the viral loads for a representative sample of individuals based on default parameter values.

Covasim is an agent-based model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. Estimates of COVID-19 symptom duration and viral shedding vary widely, with durations increasing based on symptom severity. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases, as detailed in Table 1. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or die, with a higher likelihood of death among older individuals (Table 2).

If the model includes realistic network structures (such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were chosen to align with existing studies and surveys. When considering factors like age-based susceptibility and number of contacts in each layer, the distribution of transmission events in an unmitigated scenario is roughly 30% households, 25% workplaces, 15% schools, and 30% community. The value of β can be altered by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, individual infectiousness can vary based on viral load, allowing for differences in infectivity between individuals and over time. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in New York state and Washington. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability (β) for an individual on any given day. In Figure 2, viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values are displayed. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the circumstances; estimated proportions for New York are provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced when the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but a parameter can be adjusted based on the specific modeling situation or context, considering that some studies have suggested lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
